query: What is the typical sensitivity of ultrasound transducers for medical imaging?
answer:
Question and scope. We interpret “typical sensitivity of ultrasound transducers for medical imaging” as the receive free-field voltage sensitivity of individual imaging-array elements in water/tissue, commonly expressed as V/Pa or in dB re 1 V/Pa around the center frequency. Transmit sensitivity is Pa/V and is not the focus here (though one example is noted).

Definitions. Receive sensitivity SR = Vout/Pin (V/Pa). In decibels, SR,dB = 20·log10(SR/1 V·Pa−1). Measurement is usually via calibrated hydrophone methods outlined for medical transducers. (gururaja1985piezoelectriccompositematerials pages 7-9)

Representative values in imaging bands.
- PZT/composite arrays (3–5 MHz): A phased-array test array intended for superharmonic imaging showed ~21 µV/Pa at ≈3.2 MHz, i.e., SR ≈ 2.1×10−5 V/Pa (≈ −93.6 dB re 1 V/Pa). (neer2010ultrasonicsuperharmonicimaging pages 94-97)
- Flexible piezo imaging arrays (≈5 MHz): A body-conformal 64-element imaging array reported ~4.68×10−6 V/Pa at 5 MHz (≈ −106.6 dB re 1 V/Pa). The same work reported a transmit pressure sensitivity of ~80 kPa/V for a separate modulation array (for context). (pashaei2020flexiblebodyconformalultrasound pages 10-12)
- Optical/electronic-photonic receivers (~5 MHz): A CMOS-SOI microring-resonator-based ultrasound receiver reported 7.3 mV/kPa, i.e., 7.3 µV/Pa (≈ −102.7 dB re 1 V/Pa); an alternative derivation from reported currents and transimpedance yields ~1.5 µV/Pa (≈ −116.5 dB re 1 V/Pa), in the same order of magnitude. (zarkos2023fullyintegratedelectronicphotonic pages 8-10, zarkos2023fullyintegratedelectronicphotonic pages 7-8)

Synthesis (typical range). Combining these measurements, per-element receive sensitivity for medical imaging arrays operating in the ~1–5 MHz band is typically on the order of a few to a few tens of microvolts per pascal:
- Roughly 5–25 µV/Pa, corresponding to about −107 to −92 dB re 1 V/Pa, depending on frequency, element size, backing/matching, and technology. Optical microring receivers fall toward the lower end of V/Pa but can offer competitive NEP. (neer2010ultrasonicsuperharmonicimaging pages 94-97, pashaei2020flexiblebodyconformalultrasound pages 10-12, zarkos2023fullyintegratedelectronicphotonic pages 8-10, zarkos2023fullyintegratedelectronicphotonic pages 7-8)

Notes and caveats. Reported sensitivities vary with frequency (often peaking near resonance), aperture/element area, matching layers, backing, and preamp loading. Standards literature emphasizes careful hydrophone calibration and accounting for frequency-dependent sensitivity and spatial averaging. (gururaja1985piezoelectriccompositematerials pages 7-9)
